other_tests.findings: A novel inactivating mutation (Q459R) was identified in exon 4 of both alleles of the CASR in the proband, who presented with asymptomatic hypercalcemia and hypocalciuria at age 2 years.
other_tests.changes_over_time: Subsequent levels of serum PTH were elevated in the proband, which in the context of hypercalcemia raised the possibility of primary hyperparathyroidism.

other_tests.findings: At age 2 years, the proband had normal intact PTH levels (53 pg/ml) and subsequently elevated serum PTH levels.
other_tests.changes_over_time: The relationship between serum calcium and PTH levels demonstrated suppressibility of PTH as serum calcium levels spontaneously increased.

other_tests.findings: The Q459R mutant CaSR exhibited normally expressed protein at the cell membrane but retained only 30-50% of the calcium-dependent activity of the wild-type CaSR.
other_tests.changes_over_time: The Q459R mutant demonstrated a significant decrease in responsiveness to extracellular calcium compared to wild-type CaSR.
